title: Emergency amputation necessitated within 24 hours by a human bite: a case\nreport
patient:
A 68-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with a superficial, roughly 4-cm right
forearm bite delivered by his 3-year-old grandson 24 hours earlier. The limb appeared
swollen and cyanotic, and the patient reported general discomfort for 4 hours prior to
admission. At the time of the injury, the lesion was neither washed nor disinfected. Roughly
16 hours after the injury, the patient developed swelling and pain in the distal right upper
extremity. He visited a local clinic and was diagnosed with “gout arthritis” without
laboratory confirmation and was given nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory treatment. Despite
treatment, he reported gradual worsening of the swelling and pain of the limb, purpura
around the wound and right hand, and systemic symptoms including weakness, palpitation, and
cold sweats. He then visited the emergency department of our hospital seeking further
treatment.
